div.p: RVLES OF THE ENGLISHE SODALITIE, of the Immaculate Conception of the most glorious Virgin MARY MOTHER OF GOD, In the Englishe Colledge of the Society of IESVS In Louaine.
AT MACKLINE, Printed by Henrie Iaey, 1618.

div.head: The Common Rules. FIRST PARTE. VVhat those of the Sodalitie are to obserue towards themselues.
div.p: THIS Congregaiiou or Sodalitie being instituted & founded vnder the protection of the euer B. Virgin Mother of God, & vnder the title of her immaculate Conception, Let all admitted thereunto, procure with all diligence to become singuler in the deuotiō of this Queene of heauen, & especially of this mysterie of her immaculate Conception which is the roote & origē of all her other admirable misteries.

2. The end of this Sodalitie is (by the direction of the Fathers of the
Society of Iesus,) first: that euery one therof giue himself with all dilligence, to the helpe & spirituall profite of himselfe & of his family: secondly that euery one likewise exercise charity in the workes of mercy corporall & spirituall towards his neighbours, according to his ability & commodity & as occasion shalbe offered; but aboue all the proper & peculiar exercise to be vndertaken of this Sodalitie, is to settle peace amongst enemies or ilwillers, & to appease discordes, & quarrels, dissentions & disagreementes especially betwene Catholiques of our nation, and as concerning those persons and in those cases wherin it is to be feared some great damage may ensewe: Lett therefore, those of the Sodalitie cherefully goe about with dexterity and prudence, to vnderstand and obserue such chaunces as happen
where they liue, & make the Father of the Sodalitie acquainted therewith, to the end they may haue his particuler counsell, and direction, keepinge alwaies in memory these wordes of our Sauiour; Beats pacifici, quoniam filij Dei vocabuntur, & that it was the peculiar office of the sonne of God when he came into this world to make peace betwixt the deuine Maiestie & man, & amongst men themselues. Wherefore those to whome (by the Sodalitie) it shal bee geuen in charge to make vnion and peace, let them haue regarde to doe it with great charitye and circunspectiō, to the end the difficultie be not increased which ordinarily falleth out (if care be not vsed) in this importāt & holy worke: Let them procure likewise to haue by them some treatise of fraternall loue & charitye, speaking of peace, and concorde with their neighbours; of louinge
our enemies; of pardoninge iniuries, & rendering good for euil to our brethren: And let them make familiar to themselues some liuely and efficacious reasons to induce men thereunto, whereof they may afterwards in occasions & occurrences make vse.

3. The better to attaine this ende of the Sodalitie, these may be most secure and forcible meanes praier, (especially mentall) the frequentation of Sacraments, (a thinge so profitable & necessary, to obteine victory of the fleshe worlde and deuill) diligence in abteininge vertue & Christian perfection, recollection sometime in spirituall Exercise, Mortifications, especially such as by the Father of the Sodalitie shalbe iudged most expediēt for the seruice of God, & their owne profite.

4. All are at least once euery Moneth to confesse, & afterwards in their Oratorie to cōmunicate euery first Sunday in the Moneth, & on
al the principall feasts of our Sauiour, & the B. Virgen, on the feaste of All Saints, and of the Apostles, It is left notwith standinge free to euery one to doe it more often for his greater profite, & the greater edification of others, as true mēbers of this Sodalitie; And as it is lawfull for euery one to chuse for his Confessor him who may be for his greater content, so it is likewise conuenient, that he haue one certeine, & ordinary.

5. Euery one shall spend a quarter of on hower in Mentall prayer euery day in the morning, so soone as he riseth, (for that this time is better & more certeine) or the eueninge before supper, or some other time which shalbe must conuenient, taking for his Meditatiō some pointe of the life or passion of Christ our Sauiour, chiefly accordinge to the order of the Rosarie: And for this ende it willbe meete, that euery one haue some
spiritual booke of meditations, taking for his vse those poinctes, which the Father of the Sodalitie, or his Confessour shal iudge fittest for his greater profite.

6. Euery one shal say euery day seuen Paters & as many Aues in honour of the 7. ioyes of our B. Ladij, that she may obteyne for vs the 7. gistes of the H. Ghoste, & his holy grace; hee shal also pray for his owne saluation, the helpe of sinners, the Exaltation of the holy Churche, the increase of the Sodalitie, for those which are in mortall sinne, or in dissention, & for the soules of the faithfull departed. On Saterday they shal say moreouer the hymne O gloriosa Domina with the versicles, & prayer of the Conception: And all are to knowe, that by sayinge these 7. Pater nosters, and 7. Aues in some Church of the Society of Iesus, or in some other, (where there are no Churches of the said Societie;
they gaine all the Indulgences that on those dayes are to be gayned in any Churche, either within or without the wals of Rome.

7. All are to heare Masse, as neere as they can, euery day (though it be not a holie daie) for it is a thinge verie fruitfull; But when by reason of some necessitie, or hinderance of moment they cannot doe it, let thē in place of hearinge Masse performe some other deuotion; And while they heare Masse, let them obsteine from talkinge with others, & procure to be attentiue, with much reuerence, both interriour & exteriour: Let them alsoe frequente sermons, diuine office, and often visite holy places.

8. Let euery one accustome him self, to make euery eueninge before he goe to reste, the Examen of conscience, according to those fiue pointes conteyned in the forme of the general Examen, for which
ende it is conuenient that each haue one by him ether printed or written.

9. Euery one according to the direction of his Confessour, or of the Father of the Congregation (with whome for this purpose it wilbe conuenient sometimes to deale, & treate familiarly out of the times of Congregation) must attende to the mortification of his passion, especially of those with which he is ordinarily molested, to which, will greatly helpe the particuler Examen, ordeyned for the rootinge out of vices & defectes, as the said Father shall further instructe him.

10. Let euery one afforde some tyme for the readinge of spirituall Bookes, the which is a great furtherance to prayer, and of great helpe in all other vertuous exercises: And it willbe conuenient that euery one aske the iudgemēt of the Father or his Confessour concerninge
the choyse of bookes most agreeable to his particuler defects.

11. Let them procure often to deale with the Father of the Congregation of the means to atteyne vertue, and the wayes to knowe the temptations of our ghostly enemy for their defence, & victory ouer them, for which purpose it wil auayle much to make choyce of some particuler faste in the weeke (besides those of obligation) or some other sorte of mortification.

div.head: THE SECOND PARTE. VVhat those of the Sodalitie are to obserue towards their Superiours.
div.p:
THey ought in generall & in particuler to honour, & reuerence the Father of the Congregation, as their common Father, may
dispense with the Rules, customes, & ordinances, when, & as far forth as he shall iudge expedient. Wherefore it is conueniēt nothinge of moment be handled in the Congregation, without his knowledge, & consent.

13. They shall honour also and beare all respecte to the Prefect of the Congregation, whome, as the head thereof all must promptly obey in thinges belonginge to the seruice of God, and good of the Congregation. They shall not bee wantinge also to honour and respect the 2. assistants, as chief next to the prefect and allotted to him for his aide and assistance in the gouernement, which they shall likewise performe towards all the rest of the Officers in thinges belonginge to their offices.

14. All must accepte with due promptnes & humilitie the penaūces & mortifications which shalbe enioyned them, be they for their
defectes or exercise of vertue and shall fullfill the same shewing desire of amendment: Likewise when they shalbe reprehended, or corrected by the Father or Prefect, they most heare it patiently, & humbly.

15. When to any one shalbe assigned any office, or a busines geuen in charge by the Father or Prefect, or from the Congregation, he is to accept it with all charity, & readines, and without excuse, procuringe the execution thereof with conuenient diligence. And if after mature consideration thereof, some difficultie should occurr, let him presente the same in priuate, to the end better deliberation may be taken.

div.head: THE THIRD PART. VVhat those of the Sedalitie are to obserue towards one another.
div.p: LEt them procure to loue each other with true, and syncere affection, & so maynteine peace amongst thēselues, & with others, & to remayne vnited each to the other with that stricte bond of charity, which beseemeth true children of the most B. Virgin, & members of such a Congregation, flyinge the least occasion of disunion: And when by frailtie any thinge should fall out betwene them contrary to this holy Institute of the Congregatiō, whosoeuer shall come to knowe it, he must spedily giue notice to the Father, that as soone as may be, he prouide meete & conuenient remedie.

17. When any difference, or sute for interest of goods, or other like causes should happē amongst those of the Sodality, let it be procured with fraternall charitye by meanes of the Father & Prefect, that by way of agreement, or compromise
it be ended with all speede, & loue possible.

18. When any of the Sodalitie shall fall in to sicknes, or other missortune of moment, care must be had that the Father, or Prefect, be warned as soone as may be, to the end they giue order he be visited, ayded, & comforted by others of the Congregation, with such charitable offices as are conuenient; And he to whome it apperteyneth may warne & appointe the rest such praiers as are to be made for his necessitie both corporall & spirituall.

19. When any of the Sodalitie shall departe this life, euery Priest of the Congregation shall say for his soule a Masse, the day of his death or when he hath first notice thereof (if it be possible) or as soone as may be, and the rest (as soone as they can) must procure a Masse for him, & that (if it may be) at some priuiledged Altar, applying
the Indulgences, of beades graines, medalls, & the like graūted for the diliuery of soules out of purgatory. Moreouer in their Oratorie, after a Masse of Requiem, they are to say together the whole Office of the dead. Besides for one whole Moneth those of the Sodalitie must say euery day a De profundis for the soule departed with the prayer for the dead, & 3. Paters & 3. Aues. But from these suffrages are to be excluded such as for beinge absent without leaue at the times appointed are not written in the table of those who frequente, as also those, whose far distance wholy excusinge them to frequente shall not for the space of two yeares haue written to the Sodalitie with shewe of esteme & accounte held therof. Besides lett euery one remember to recommend in generall to our Lord in their prayers the soules of all the Sodalitye departed.

20. When suffrages are to be geuē or consultation to be helde, or treatie to be made, for the receauinge of any into the Congregation, or for the election of Prefecte, assistants, Consultors, or other officers, or busenes of that nature which require voyce, or consultation, Let euery one procure to proceede without humane respect, with all freedome & synceritye of intention, choosinge alwaies them, whome in their conscience they shall iudge meete for the purpose, hauinge only regard to the greater honour of God and common good of the Sodalitie.

div.head: THE FOVRTH PARTE. VVhat those of the Sodalitie are to obserue towards their neighbours.
div.p:
LEt them flie not only all ill Company & all manner of occasions,
which may bringe perill to their soules, as gaminge, and dissolute places, procuringe to conuerse often, and for the most parte, with such as may be a helpe vnto them by their good examples, keepinge themselues free from all vnbeseeminge speaches, from scandalous murmuringes, & other inconueniences, the which (besides the offence of God) diminishe the good name, & credite of the Congregation, & the fame of their neighbours; But let them also endeuour to be very exemplar in their words, life, & actions to the edification of their neighbours, & with all not to be wanting with charitable counsailes to exhorte them to vertue, and integrity of life, frequentinge of the Sacramentes, to meditation, & mental prayer, exercises so profitable for the good of soules: And finally lett them imploye them themselues willingly in the seruice,
& healpe of their said neighbours aswel tēporall as spirituall. 22. These of the Sodalitie must not onelie be content to knowe well themselues the Christian doctrine, or catechisme, but they must also procure that all their familie likewise knowe the same, aswell their childerē & kindred, as also their seruauntes, & such as dwel with them, to whome they mufl afforde a conuenient ime to learne it, and to satisfie all other obligations of christian dutie; As to heare Masse euery Sonday and holie daie; To confesse and communicate at their appointed times exhortinge them to doe it many times in the yeare, & likewise to obserue all the commaundemēts of God, & of the Holy Churche, prouidinge in the best manner possible, that in their house his diuine Maiestie be not offended, nor yet that there be any occasion thereof.

div.head: THE FIFTE PART. VVhat they are to obserue towards the Sodality it self.
div.p: ALl must be dilligent in comminge to the Congregation, or Sodalitie, on those dayes on which it is held, that is euery Saterday, & Sonday, and all the Feastes of our Sauiour, his glorious Mother, (of precepte) on the day of all Sainctes, & the feastes of the Apostles, which lighte vpon wensday. And let them performe with attention & denotion, the exercises of meditation, & mentall prayer, conference, discourses, & other accustomed exercises of the Congregation, as the Father shall iudge the qualitie, & comoditie of time, busines, occasions, & particular needes of the Congregation to require.

24. Let euery one with all diligence endeuour to come in due
time to the Congregation, layinge aside all busines for the honour of God & his most glorious Mother, notwith standinge if any iust impediment shall happen to any, let him aduertise the Father, or Prefecte, & fayling herein lett him supplye it in the first Congregation followinge.

25. Although the mortificatiōs, penaunces, & other like secrets of the Congregation ought to remaine priuate amongst those only that be of it (vnles some one were to be enformed thereof, the which should truly pretend, and were readie to enter) notwithstāding it is not forbidden by this, to let anie one leade to the Congregation some frende which is not of it, to moue him with that good example to enter therein, so it be done with licence of the Father or Prefecte; but at such times it is better to refraine from geuinge of penaunces, or mortifications to any,
who should not of himself demaunde them.

26. As for their places in the Oratorie, regarde is not to be had to any sorte of precedencie, neither in the oratory it self, nor in goinge out thereof, to auoyde all ceremonies, & ambition; And in their departure, let them vse such modestie & composition, in their gate, in their speache, and all the rest of their actions, that euery one may reape good example thereby & take notie of the profite made by their spirituall exercise of the Sodality.

27. Seeing those of the Congregation come together purposely, to make some recollection, & sequester themselues for an hower & a half from worldly affaires, the better to vnite them selues with God, they must keepe continuall silence in their Oratory, euery one attendinge to him self, & abstayninge from talkinge with
others, euen of spirituall thinges, much more of worldly, curious, & vaine matters.

28. When Conference is made of spirituall matters, or other affaires are treated, let those of the Sodalitie expecte till they be askt, neither propoundinge, nor answeringe (if they be not demaūded) either in generall, or particuler. Yf notwithstandinge any one of them for iust causes would speake or propounde any thinge to the Congregation publiquely, lett him not doe it, without first hauing asked licence of the Father: And let them beware, in deliueringe their opinions, to dispute & impugne, the sayinges of others or to contende: But if in any thinge, one should be of contrary iudgement to an other, and it should seeme good to declare it, let him bringe his reasons with modestie, and charitye, and with an intente that truthe may haue place, & that
that may be done which is beste, slyinge all shewe of desire to become superiour in his owne opinion.

29. When any is to goe out of the Citty some long voyage, or to remayne abroade some long time let him acquainte the Father, or Presect, & at due time lett him demaunde, or procure, that licence may publiquely be asked in his behalf in the Congregation, and let him take his patent of the Prefecte & of the Assistantes, that he may be admitted in other Congregations, & also to the ende that when he returneth, he may be acknowledged, & accepted of, in this Congregation without further testimony. Let him procure also in the place of his abode, to obserue (as much as is possible) the Rules of the Congregation, & performe the exercises thereof, in particuler, their mentall prayer, examinatiō of conscience, pursute of vertue,
frequentinge of the Sacraments, & exampie of good life, exercisinge them selues also in some workes proper to the Congregation, as in peace-makinge or other workes of mercie, and helpe of their neighbours. Let him remēber also to pray often for the spirituall aduauncemēt, & good progresse of the Sodalitie: as the Soda-litie is in like manner to pray for him; And if he is to be longe absent, let him nowe and then giue accompte of himself by letter to the Congregation; And this at leaste once euery half yeare.

30. Whilest those of the Sodalitie are meetinge together in the Oratorie, one of the Lectors appointed shal reade some spirituall booke assigned by the Father: The same is to be done, whilest vpon any occasion stay is made of any of the ordinary exercises.

31. Those that shal make instance to be admitted into the Congregation,
let them doe it by way of memorial: They must be syncere Catholikes resolued to liue well, & endewed with other particuler qualites which by the Congregatiō are lefte to the discretion of the Father: and if they be such, as are not fully knowne (at least) by some of the Sodalitie, or some of the Fathers of the Societie, let it be cōmitted to one or two of the Congregation (acordinge as it shall seeme best to the secret consult) that they take certeine information, whether such qualities concurre, as are requisite, which beinge founde wantinge, they are in good manner to be put of, but if they shalbe iudged fit by the Sedalitie, then they are to be admitted to their probatiō. Before their admittance, all are to make a generall Confession of their whole life, with whome they haue most deuotiū: And if already they haue made one a litle before, it is sufficient
to make another, beginninge from their last, & it would be very profitable vnto them, to make for some dayes the spirituall Exercises of the Societie of Iesus, instituted by Blessed Father Ignatius, founder of the same (if so be, they feele them selues inclined thereunto) furthermore, before they be admitted, lett them haue frequented the Congregation (at the least for 3. monethes, so farre forth as their occasiōs permitt) & be well informed, & instructed of those thinges which are obserued therein, they are to see these present Rules to the end they may consider them well, and resolue them selues, if they can, and will fullfill what is conteyned in the, whereof one, or both of the Assistantes, some Counsultour, or some other deputed by the secret Congregation shall haue care: Afterwards, when they are to be admitted, their Instructours must
first in their absence make that full & ample relation, of which is treated in the particuler Rules of the Instructours. And beinge to proceede to the acte of admission let it be done with the consente of the greater parte of those, that are present in the Congregation, by secret suffrages, and in absence of them of whose admittance they treate, & beinge accepted of, then they shalbe brought in afterwards at the first ensewinge Congregation. Finally, All are to haue these Rules, that nowe, and then, they may renewe, and refreshe the memory of them; And they must be read in full Congregation at the first oportunitie after the choosinge of newe officers. And as it is not intended that any who shall fayle in the obseruance of them, should incurre any sorte of sinne (euen veniall) so by obseruinge them, (besides that he shall obteyne most efficacions helpe to
true spirituall life) he shal moreouer gayne very great, & particuler merite in the sighte of God, & his most glorious Mother; To whome be geuen glory, & prayses for euer.

div.head: Particuler Rules For the Officers of the Congregatiō. Rules belonginge to the Prefect.
div.p: THe Prefect, as he excelleth the rest in degree, & office, so he ought to endeuour to excell them in vertue, & exact obseruance of al the Rules.

2. Let him embrace the gouernement with great charitie, and procure to applye himself with
all diligence thereunto, as a thinge of great importance for the seruice of God, & the most Blessed Virgin; And let him be carefull to come alwaies in time, as well to geue good example, as to prouide for all thinges, which (by the aduice of the assistants) shall seeme necessary for the Congregation.

3. He is to consulte with the Eather of the Congregation, & with his Assistants (before he ordeyne any thinge) all the particuler thinges which shall occurre in the gouernement of the Congregation, either belonginge to the spirituall profite of those of the Sodalitie, or any other matter; And therefore euery Saterday, or Sunday (in fit place) he shall treate with them, & for that purpose he shall haue a booke, in which he shall distinctly note (for his better memory) al that which he is to consult or ordeyne.

4. When there occurreth some
weightie matter, (for which greater consideration is required, & therefore it may seeme necessary to haue the aduice of many) he may (if it seeme good to the Father) call (besides the two Assistantes) the Consultours, with whome also euery first Saterday of the Moneth he shall treate, howe those of the Congregation doe procede, howe the Rules be obserued, And whether there be necessitie to make any ordinance for the good of the Sodalitie.
5. When any one is receaued into the Congregation let him presently procure that the booke of Rules be geuen him.

6. When he shall vnderstand that any of the Sodalitie is sicke, he shall cause him to be visited, as it shall seeme most conuenient, Inquiringe afterwards the necessities of the sick person, procuringe also that to be performed for his tēporall & spirituall helpe which
is conteyned in the 18. common Rule.

7. When any of the Congregation shall die, he shall haue care that (as soone as may be) the ordinary obligatiōs be performed for him, according to the 19. cōmon Rule: And when the deceased person shall leaue behinde him Childrē, poore, and in necessitie, he shall procure that a consulte be made in presence of the Father, with the Assistantes, and Consultours, howe to succour them accordinge to their necessity & qualitie, & abilitie of the Congregation.

8. When any ordinances are to be made, either by way of decree in writtinge, or in other manner, he shall procure with the Father, & assistantes, that the secret Congregation be assebled, in the which they shall deliberate & decree so much as is expediente, & beeinge thinges fit to be published, or confirmed in the generall Congregatiō,
the deliberation, or decree made in the secret, shalbe proposed in the generall, to the ende, that (by Gods grace) that which is decreed may be better obserued.

9. It doth belonge to the Prefecte (if he happen to be a Prieste) to say before the Congregation, the accustomed praiers & letanies of our B. Lady, the Prayer Actiones nostras &c. before meditation, & meditation ended, to intone, the Magnificat, and after, say the prayer Famulis tùis &c. & at the ende of the Congregation, to beginne, & prosecute together the Salue Regina, or Alma Redemptoris, or Aue Regina coelorum, or Regina coeli, with the versicle, and prayer for the time: As also to beginne the Prayers, hymnes, Psalmes, & say all the prayers, & letanies, which are accostomed to be said at the distribution of Sainctes, before, & after admissions, before, & after the priuate Congregation, & to doe the office, in sayinge
the prayers when the office of the dead shalbe recited, & performe the office in the Mattens, of tenebras, and in the houres of the three dayes of the holy weeke: To performe the office in the Vespers of the Eue of the Conception: All which offices ought to be performed by him with the Rochet, (yf he be a Prelate) Therefore, it is conuenient, that he prepare himself in due time for all the aforesaid actions, and other such like, perusinge before, all the thinges which belonge vnto him to say, & doe, that he may perfectly performe his office in the sighte of all the Congregation.

div.head: Rules of the two Assistantes.
div.p:
THe office of the 2. Assistantes, is, to assiste the Prefect, and helpe him in the gouernement of
the Congregation, & therefore they ought to sit neere vnto him, (that is) the first, on the righte hand, & the secōd on the lefte: And when the Prefecte is absent, the first Assistant must supplie his place in gouernement; And the first Assistant also beinge absente, the second shall supplie; In which cases they shall haue the same authoritie, & the same obligatiō to obserue the Rules of the Prefecte.
2. Let them procure to be very exemplar in vertue, & exact in the obseruance of all the Rules.

3. The Assistants ought particularly to affecte, & seeke the good gouernement of the Congregation, & be diligente in cominge to the same, for the example of the rest, and helpe of the Prefect in thinges that shall occurre.

4. When they deliuer ther opinions, they shall doe it with all modesty, & without passion, hauing regard to the seruice of God,
& the most B. Virgin, & to the good of the Sodality: and what shalbe treated with the Prefect, or determined, they shall keepe in secret, as well from strangers, as from those of the Sodalitie, it beinge the office of the Prefect to publishe (when it salbe necessary) the determinations, and other thinges which shalbe done. And if in their resolutions, there happen diuersitie of opinions betwene the Assistants & the Prefecte, let it be signified vnto the Father, that he may prouide as shalbe expedient.

5 Let them knowe that of thēselues they cannot ordeyne any thinge, and when it shall occurre vnto them, to propose some thinge for the furtheringe of the rest in spirite, or for the helpe of the Congregation, or of the workes which it hath embraced, they may represent it vnto the Father, or to the Prefecte, remittinge themselues vnto them (after they haue
proposed it) in all that shalbe determined in our Lord.
6. The Assistants also ought to put the Prefecte in minde of thinges concerninge the gouernement of the Congregation.

7. And bycause the Assistants are likewise accoustomed to giue Instructours, to those that desire to be admitted into the Congregatiō, they must obserue that which is ordeyned in the 6. Rule of the Consultours, & more amplie in the Rules of the Instructours.

div.head: Rules of the Secretarie of the Congregation.
div.p:
THe Secretarie must be present at all the actions of the Congregation, as well publique, as priuate, he shall write in a booke (appointed for that purpose) the thinges that shalbe done: He shall haue
a Cheste, or deske locked with a key, where he shall lay vp all the thinges of his office well kept, & in good order, that they may easily befounde whē soeuer there shalbe neede, & that afterwards he may resigne them vnto his successour: he must also be mindfull of due secrecie; wherefore he shall not talke with any of thinges determined, or to be determined in the Congregation, nor shewe any writinge, without order, or knowledge of the Father, or Prefecte.

2. He shall haue two other bookes, one litle, & the other greater, the lesse shall serue to note the names, surnames, countrey, & profession of those that shalbe admitted into the Congregation, as well after three monethes probation, as by vertue of patentes, or other certeine testimonies wich come from forraine Congregations, and therin he shall note the day of his
admission: And that little booke shal serue, that after a yeare expired, they may take out of it, and transferre into the greater booke the names, surnames, countreyes, profession, and day of admission of those, which for that yeare haue diligently frequented the Congregation as it behooueth; and in the same great booke he shall keepe, an accounte of those that chaunge their state. Moreouer, he shall haue a litle booke in which he shall note those that departe, especially who are not likely to returne.

3. He shall write those letters which occurre to be written in the name of the Congregatiō, & shall geue Patentes to those that take any iourney, sealinge the one & the other with the accustomed seale of the Congregation (all not withstanding by order of the Father and Presect) And he shall alwaies haue a Register of the
thinges of momente, especially of the decrees which shalbe made; of the Patentes which are geuen to such as departe; & of those who shalbe brought from other Congregations, and of theire acceptance.

4. He shall haue an vnder-secretarie which may helpe him to write, & in his absence assiste in his place; but that vnder Secretary must not be present at the consultations, vnles sometime it seeme otherwise expedient to the Father & Prefect.

5. He shall haue care that in the Oratorie, at the entrance of the dore, on one fide, there be a table with the names & surnames of all of the Congregaiion (yet liuinge) & on the other side another table of the names, and surnames of those that frequente the Congregation, & neere vnto that, another of those that frequente (which are not Priestes) that they may signe them
that are to communicate. And also let there be in the oratorie, or in some other fit, and conuenient place, the Bull of the erection of the Congregation, the common Rules, a sumne of the Indulgences, and other thinges as shalbe ordeyned by the Father & Prefect.

6. He shall haue a care to reade, or see read euery Saterday, the plenary & other notable Indulgences, which in the weeke follow inge may be gayned by those of the Congregation, and also in due times the Rules, and all other thinges which shall occurre to be read in the Congregation.

7. It shal be also his care to call those of the Sodalitie one by one, by name, & surname to goe and take the suffrages, when they shalbe distributed, & to call also in Sundayes Congregations by name, and surname, those, that are that weeke to visite the Hospitall (prouided that they be of those then
present at the Congregation.

8. Likewise he shall haue care to make a bill of those which shal make their houre of prayer in the quarant-houer, hauing regarde that the houres lesse commodious be assigned to those that dwel not so farr of: And it is to be noted, that the said bill be fastned in the Oratorie (at the least) the morninge of the day goinge before
9 He shall doe diuers other thinges, which occurrēces of actions shal declare to belōge to his office, & which also shalbe assigned vnto him by the Father, or Prefecte.

div.head: Rules of the Consultours of the Congregation.
div.p:
THe office of the Consultours, is to ayde with their counsaile, & helpe the Prefect in his charge,
for which it is expediēt that they be very zealous in the seruice of our Lorde, & of the B. Virgin, and of the good progresse, & spirituall helpe of the Congregation: They must also be well vnited with the Prefect, & amongst them selues, in fraternall charitie.

2 They shall procure in all thinges belōginge to the Congregatiō, & in the obseruāce of their Rules, to be the first, that the others moued by their exāple be more diligēte. 3. When soeuer the Father, or Prefect, shall call them to consulte, they must shewe thēselues readie, & deliuer plainely, ther opinions, and when there shalbe variance, euery one must tell his reasons, without touchinge, or reprehendinge others, & if they goe about to confute the reasons of others, they must doe it in such manner, that they giue no signes of contradictiō, but only to confirme that which they iudge conuenient.

4 If some thinge occurre to any of them, profitable for the vniuersall good of the Congregation, he may propounde it priuately vnto the Father, or Prefect, remittinge himself afterwards to that which they shall determine.
5. They are also to haue care to keepe secret that which is treated in the Consultes, not only from others, but also from them of the Congregation it self.

6. When there shalbe assgned vnto them by the officers & Consultour, any of those who demaūde entrance into the Congregation, to be instructed, they must haue particuler care to instructe, & directe them well in thinges concerning the said Congregation, and let them reuiewe diligently, the particuler Rules of the Instructours, procuringe to obserue them punctually.

div.head: The Rules of the Instructours of those which desire to enter into the Sodalitie.
div.p: WHen the Father shall commit to any the memoriall of some persō (not knowne) who desireth to enter into the Sodalitie, they must with all diligence informe themselues of his qualitie, & geue accounte of their information with all speede, vnto the Congregation, that it may quickly be resolued, whether he is to be proposed or no, to the Sodalitie, for his admittance to probation; and to this end let them reade what is conteyned in the 31. common Rule.

2. After any shalbe admitted to the said Probation, the Instructours must see that duringe the time thereof, they fullfill what soeuer
is prescribed in the forenamed 31 common Rules, which treateth particulerly hereof, especially about the generall Confession, in that manner, which in the foresaid Rule is declared.

3. They must shewe them all the common & particuler Rules, with the customes of the Sodalitie. which often they must inculcate, declaringe vnto them that which they doe not well vnderstad, that they may resolue whether they can, and will obserue them. And to be briefe, they must instructe them of what soeuer they are to doe, as well duringe the time of their Probation, as after their admission.

4. It apparteyneth also to their care, to instructe them exactly, in that which they are to doe on the day of their admittance, and on the day whē they are publiquely to be brought in into the Sodalitie, which shalbe the first day of
Congregation, after the day of their admittance, for which ende it behooueth the Instructours, & the persons instructed, to peruse diligently the forenamed 31 common Rule.

5 They must endeuour that those who me they instructe, be taught the maner of cōmendinge themselues to God, euery morninge, to examine their consciences at night, as also to pray mentally, & to liue like good Christians.

6 They must haue care to warne the Father & the Prefect, when the time of their probatiō is expired. 7. That, which by all meanes the Instructour is to obserue, when the partie by him instructed is to be admitted, (that those of the Congregation, may with a safe conscience geue their voyce) is, as followeth, first he must admonishe the partie (to be admitted) to goe out of the Oratorit Secondly, he shall with a loude voyce say,
howe such an one (tellinge name, surname, countrey, state and profession) was so long since admitted by the secret Congregation, to his probation, and that he was assigned for his Instructour: That he hath endeuoured to instructe him according to the Rules of the Sodalitie, as well as he could: That the three monethes of probation are expired: That he hath made a generall Confessiō of his whole life, or from his last generall, of which he hath sufficiently certified the Father of the Sodalitie: howe he himself hath obserued, that the said partie hath, duringe the terme of the three monethes (when he was not laufully hindred) not only frequented diligently the Sodalitie, but also the holy Sacraments: That he hath shewed a good & christian spirite: That he seemeth to him sufficiently instructed in the Rules of the Sodalitte, & in what else so euer
a good menber of the same is bounde to obserue. That he sheweth a good and resolute will, to put them in execution: That he show a purpose, at tymes appointed to frequent the Sodalitie: And that for all the respectes aforesaid, he doe verily iudge him worthie to be admitted into the same and hopeth it wil haue good successe. Thirdly, after that by suffrages he shall be admitted, the Instructour must aduertise him, that the Sodalitie hath receaued him: that the next Congregatiō, he is to be brought in, after the accustomed manner set downe in the Customes; That cōmunicatinge on the day of his entrance, at the Masse of the Sodalitie, either first, or seconde, he gayneth a plenary Indulgence. Fourthly, in the next Sodalitie, at the end of the meditation, he shall cause the partie, to goe out againe of the Oratorie, and shall put the Father in minde of his
entrance to be reade, & the Father geuing him order so to doe, he shall goe out to bringe him in; And at the doore the Sacristans shall receaue him, accomponie & directe him in the rest of the actions, & ceremonies accustomed in such times, as is set downe in the sixte rule of the Sacristans, and in the foresaid chapter of the Customes.

div.head: Rules of the Sacristans of the Sodalitie.
div.p: THe Sacristans are to haue care of the Chappell, & of all thinges perteyninge to the vse thereof and therefore they must alwaies come the first, (at least half an hower) before the time of the Sodalitie, to prepare all thinges necessary for Masse.

2. They shall haue care to dresse the Altar with ornamentes answerable to the times both festivall and feriall withsuche other offices, and functions as are to be done, dispatchinge all eyther the day before, or when else wilbe more commodious for them.

3. Eight dayes before the generall communion, at the end of the Congregation, they shall admonishe all, eyther by themselues, or by meanes of the Father, that the next Sundy wilbe the first of the moneth, that they may prepare themselues to communicate.
4. They shall also haue care to prepare the suffrages of the Sainctes, euery moneth, and to haue them ready, to be deuided the Saterdayes Congregation, next before the beginninge of the newe moneth.

5. It belonges also to their charge, to prouide all thinges
necessary for the geuinge of voyces, whensoeuer, either for admittance, election of Officers, or any other busines of like nature is to be done, and they must goe about with the thinges, prouided for that purpose.

6 It is their office also to receaue at the doore, and leade betwene them the newe admitted to the place of prayer before the Altar, and to accompany them to the Magistrats benche, to be embraced, accordinge to the custome.

7 They shall also haue the charge to aduertise timely those, which are to reade the Lessons in all the offices which in the Congregation are to be said, leadinge them to the deske, and to bringe them back againe (betweene thē) to their places, obseruinge particulerly what is set downe in the sixte chapter, of the custome concerninge the diuine office.

8. They must haue a diligent
care timely to hange vp at the Oratory doore, the table with the names & surnames of thē which are not Priestes that will receiue at the first Masse, remembringe, that when they put the Pixe with hostes vpon the Altar, for the offertorie, that they put so many hostes as there are names signed, and so manie more as they may probably gesse will come persons to communitate after the offertory, putting rather alwaies to many then to fewe: And the same is to be obserued for the communiō in the second Masse after the Congregation. Likewise euery day of communion (as well generall, as particuler) to make a bill of all them that doe communicate, and to giue it to the Father, at the end of the moneth,
9. They must prepare the Candles for Candelmas day, the Palmes for Palme Sunday, in due time.

10. They must admonishe betimes the Father or Presecte, of what soeuer wanteth in the Sacristie, that it maybe prouided, & must haue a booke, to write therein what soeuer is laid out: Neither must they lay out any thinge, much or litle, for the Oratorie, without first acquaintinge the Father, or Prefect.

11 They must keepe a booke, wherein they shall make a very exact, & faithfull Inuētorie of all thinges belōging to the Oratory (be they neuer so litle) & when soeuer newe Sacristans shall succeede, & the olde goe out, they must all together with two others (assigned by the Father, & Prefect) reuewe the said Inuentorie, adioyning thereunto What soeuer hath beene made, or geuen, or come thither of newe, for the seruice of the Chappel, or vse of the Congregation, (which is not already written.)

div.head: Rules of the Treasourer.
div.p: THe Treasourers office is, to keepe the money which they of the Sodalitie shall offer for the necessities thereof, & which by any other meanes shall come to the Congregation, and to geue it out to those persons, which the Prefect shall appointe in the manner, and forme, as the rule prescribeth.

2. He must keepe a booke of what he receaues, and layes out, And as concerninge what is receaued, he must note with the greatest distinction, and perspicuitie possible, all the sommes which he receaues, specifyinge the causes, and the dayes, & with the same diligence, he must note what soeuer is layd out, specifyinge also the causes, dayes, and the order geuen.

3. He must also exacte of euery one what they are to geue for the ordinary expences of the Congregaiion; And he must so distinctly put it downe in writinge, that it may be cleerely seene howe much euery one hath geuen, and what he is yet to geue, that so he may sometimes remember them, & exacte it of them.
4. For the expences to be made for the vse of the Congregation, he must not geue any mony to what persons soeuer, without order from the Prefect in Writinge.

5. When the Treasourer shall geue mony to any one, to be spente in small matters for the Oratories vse, as to Sacrictans, or other such like, let him note it particularly, in the booke of expences, to the end, that those which haue receaued the money, may render their accounte of the small expences, & geue a bill thereof to the Prefecte, who must reuiewe it, to the end,
that what soeuer they shall haue laid out (besides) of their owne, may be restored vnto them, or not hauing laid out all, it may serue for the next expences they are to make, which bills (for good order sake, after the Prefect hath seene them) are to begeuen to the Secretarie, to keepe.
6. Euery 2. monethes, the Treasourer is to geue vnto the Prefect, a distincte accounte of the administration of the receiptes, & expences, which afterwards is to be geuen to the Secretarie to keepe.

div.head: The Rules of the Porters.
div.p: THey must come (the first) to open the Oratory doore, & to see it be swept, handsome, & the seates well placed.

2. They must sit neere to the doore, and must admonishe those
that come, to signe their names in the table of those that frequent, and those (besides) that wil communicate, to signe their names in the table for that purpose. Let them also procure that all take their places as they come, close one to another, that when others come, they may finde empty place, without stirringe, & mouinge for euery one that comes.

3. They must haue a care that none enter into the Congregation that are not of it, vnles they haue particuler leaue of the Father, or Prefect, that none enter armed: And if sometime any stranger should insinuate himself, and enter in the Oratory to see what is done therein; It is the care of the Porters (hauing regard to the qualitie of the person) in good fashion to aduise him that he goe forthe, or else to dissemble sor one only time. & let him alone, (especially if he be a Prelate, or Gentilman
of accounte; & there be no secret busines to be treated in the Congregation, or action to be done, at the which straungers presence would be disconuenient) But, if the same partie should continue to come; It is the custome that the Porters tell him the second time freely, but withall modestly that it please him to retire him self thence, or else to demaund licence of the Father or Prefect, to remaine.

4. Let them note all those that shall haue come to euery Congregation, and those, that shall at anie time be wantinge (acordinge to the Table) geuinge afterwards the said note vnto the Father, to the end he may aiwaies knowe truly who hath frequēted, when, & howe ofte.

div.head: Rules of the Readers.
div.p: LEt him to whome (by turne) it apperteyneth to reade, procure to come betime, & about one quarter of an howre before the time assigned for Masse (though the nomber of the assembled be small) let him beginne to reade in that booke, & with that order that the father shal haue assigned, & let him cōtinue on till the Priest come forth to say Masse: And if he shall see, that after Masse there be some hinderance for the other exercises, let him reade againe till such time as they beginne.
2. Let him endeuour to reade readily, distinctly, & with an intelligible voyce, and let him sit where euery one may easily vnderstand him.

3. When he shalbe hindered to come, let him geue notice thereof,
to one of the other Readers, that he may supplie for him, and also, when the others shall marke that he to whome it apperteyneth is wantinge, let them procure to supplie them selues accordinge to the order assigned.
4. Let him that readeth, procure to lay afterwards the booke in his place, & note where he lefte readinge, that it may be afterwards orderly continued.

div.head: Rules of those that visite the Sicke.
div.p:
SO soone as they shal knowe that any of the Congregation be sick, let them endeuour (with all diligence) to goe & visite them, & when they shall see that the sick receaue content, & comforte by their visite, let them visit them oftener. Let them also be diligent
in relatinge vnto the Father, or Presect, the state of the sick, not only the first time, but others also, (especially when they shalbe in daunger of death) since that on this their diligence dependeth, that the said Father, or Prefecte, may ordeyne prayer to be made for their corporall, & spiritual health as also suffrages, when death succeedeth: Neither is it necessary that the office of visitinge, be done in one, & the self same time, of all the visitours, but two at a time wilbe sufficient, and when that cannot be, one only, & so deuided, they may better supplie the visites when there shalbe more sick.

div.head: CVSTOMES Of the Congregation, About the gouernement, & the officeres of the Congregation.
CHAPTER 1.
div.p: HE that principally gouerneth, and directeth the Congregation, (especially in spirituall thinges) is one of the Fathers of the Societie of Iesus; After him, the Prefect hath the first place, who must be one of the Congregation, either an ecclesiasticall person or lay-man.

To the Prefect are appointed two Assistants, vnto which immediatly followeth the Secretatie of the Cōgregatiō, who hath an vnder-Secretarte,
that supplieth in all thinges for him whē he is absent.
All the foresaid fiue are accustomed to sit on the benche of the Magistrates.

There are besides these other officers following (which may be increased, or doubled accordinge to the nomber of the Sodality) 6. Consultours, 2. Sacristans, one Treasourer, 2: Porters, 2. Readers, & 2. Visitours of the Sick of the Congregation.

When the Prefect is wantinge, or is hindered for some short time, so that he cannot be present at the Congregation, the first Assistant gouerneth in his place, & when the first Assistant is wantinge, the second supplieth: And though it seldome happen, that all be wantinge when there is neede; neuertheles (when it shall so happē) the Father of the Congregation is neuer wantinge. But when it happeneth that the Prefect departeth
(not to returne with in the time of his office, or is to haue some long ympedimente so that he cannot be present at the Congregations at times appointed) then the whole Congregation proceedeth to make choyce of another in his place, & the same is to be obserued touchinge the two Assistants. Other Officers are substituted by the particular Congregation only, accordinge to necessitie & occurrences.

div.head: About the choyce of Officers.
CHAPTER 2.
div.p:
THe election of officers is made thrice a yeare (to wit) about the Feastes of the Conception, Anuntiation, & the Assumption of the glorious Virgin: The Prefect & the 2. Assistants are chosē by the whole Congregation; The other officers by the particular Congregatiō only, who (as is supposed) hath more
distincte, and more intrinsecall knowledge of all in the Sodalitie: And all is done after the manner followinge.

In the Congregation which goeth before the day appointed for the election of the Prefect, & the 2. Assistants, notice is geuen of the said future, election, & the names of all that haue actiue, and passiue voyces are read by the Secretarie, to renewe by that meanes the memory of all: In the same Congregatio also is read all this chapter cōcerninge the electiō of officers.

Afterwards on the day it self of election, Masse being said, with the prayer of the holy ghoste, and immediatly before the election, the ordinary prayers, and Letanies of our B. Lady, the Father, or Prefect, with some shorte discourse, exhorteth all to proceede in the election without any worldly passion, regardinge only the glory, and seruice
of God, and the spirituall good of the Congregation.
Then is said the hymne Veni Creator Spiritus with the prayer Deui qui corda Fidelium.

After which, in certeine litle papers prepared for that effect by the Secretary, with other necessaries to write, euery one writeth the name only of the persō whome he chooseth for future Prefect, he foldes it, and presentes it at the benche before the Father, who, together with the Prefect, compareth first the nomber of all the suffrages, with the nomber of the assembled, to see how the names giuen in and the persons that are to giue their voyces do agree, he readeth afterwards to the hearing of all, the suffrages: and the Secretarie hath care to note the names of them that are chosen, and the nomber of suffrages as they are geuen to euery one.

This scrutinie beinge ended, he that hath more then half the suffrages, is by the Father, declared newe Prefect of the Corgregation, & being led betwene two of the Sacristans, after a litle prayer made before the Altar, he is placed in one of the Chayers (prepared by thē for that purpose) in the midst of the Oratorie, (to wit) in that which is the midle of the three, & this done, they are to proceede to the election of the two Assistants in the like manner.

Afther this, the Prefect, and 2. Assistants that haue ended their offices, one after the other, kneelinge in the midst of the Oratorie before the Father, accuse themselues openly of their faultes cōmitted in their gouernement and humbly demaundinge penance, receaue frō the father that which is geuen them, not returninge any more to the benche.

This done, Te Deum Laudamus is
said, with the prayer Deus cuius misericordia, & the reste of the Congregation departed, to sauinge the Prefectt, the Assistāts newly chosen, the former Prefect, & Assistants, together with the rest of the Particular Congregation, and the Father, who chuse the other officers, accordinge to the order as they are before named, and obseruinge that which hereafter shalbe said: & the suffrages are in like manner noted by the Secretarie.

In the Cougregation followinge, the Prefect, & the 2. newe Assistants, after Masse, and the accustomed prayers, & Letanies, goe to sit on the benche in place of those who ended, & the Prefect, or Father at his request, saieth briefly somewhat for edification, before any other exercise beginne.

The same day, the old Secretarie publisheth by wordeof mouth the officers newly chosen, & the old accuse thēselues in like mānner
before the Father, of their faultes, & receaue penaunces.

Finally the old Secretarie readeth, or causeth to be read the common Rules of the Congregation (in case the Father iudgeth it not expedient to deferre it till another time) and the said Father exhorteth all to the entire obseruāce of them, notinge some particuler thinge wherein defecte is seene.
Hauinge thus proceeded the oulde Secretarie yealdeth his place to the newe, and goeth to accuse himself, & receate penaunce, as the other officers haue done.

The election of the Prefect, and the 2. Assistants, is alwaies made by scrutinie, with the greater parte of the voyces of those which are present in Congregation, so as they are to exceede the half (as before hath beene said) And when in the first scrutinie there falles out equall voyces betweene
two then they procede to the second in which no other can be chosen then one of those betweene whome the equalitie fell in the precedent scrutinie; And in case they fall equall againe in nomber of suffrages, lotts are cast, and he is chosen whose name is drawne out: But if in the first scrutinie those that concurre were more then two by equalitie of voyces, they are to be brought to two only, by a newe scrutinie, or by billets or ballottinge, which not succeedinge, they afterwards cast lotts to determine the two concurrences: the election of the other officers, is made either by scrutinie, or word of mouth, as it best pleaseth the particuler Congregation.

The Prefect, & Assistants, are not wonte to be confirmed in their offices aboue once only, the same is to be obserued for the most parte in the other officers,
exceptinge these in whose offices more particuler, & long practise is required, as are the Secretarte, of the Congregation, the Sacristans, and the Treasourer.

Except the Prefect, (and when the nomber is great) the Assistants also, & Secretarie of the Congregation, more offices may concurre in one & the self same person, so the offices them selues be not contrary.
No man in what soeuer electiō hath more then one voyce, no not the Father, nor Prefect himself.

div.head: About the daies on which the Congregation is held.
CHAPTER 3.
div.p:
BEsides the dayes appointed in the Rules, (which are the Saterdayes, & Sundayes of all the yeare, all the Feastes of our Sauiour, & of our B. Lady (of precept)
the feasts of the holy Apostles that fall vpon wensday, & the Feastes of all Sainctes, the Congregation is to be held on other dayes also for diuers occasions, either on the peculiar Feast of the Congregation or the offices of the Holy weeke.

For the better solemnizinge their proper Feast, which is that of the Immaculate Conception of our B. Lady, they are wont to assemble them selues together for 8. dayes before the said Feast; euery morninge to heare Masse; to say the Letanies of our B. Lady, and to make a quarter of an hower of mentall prayer vpon thes pointes which the Father proposeth: Further they must assemble thēselues also on the Eue to say Vesperas.

To celebrate the offices of the Holy weeke, they must assemble themselues the 3. dayes in which they are said, as well in the eueninge as the morninge, & further, on holy thursday morninge, for
Masse & communicate in the said Oratorie, & for the cōference vpon the B. Sacramente; After which, they are wonte to goe into the Churche, to attend on the most holy Body of our Lord to the Sepulcher: And on holy Saterday morninge (besides the howers which are first said) there are read also the prophecies, & Masse following at which it is fit al shoulde be present: To the prayer before the B. Sacramen in the Oratorie for the necessities of our Countrey, they also assemble themselues the day appointed, accordinge to the maner conteyned in the customes about the quarant-hower.

On Easter Sunday (by reason of the bond which euery Christian hath to cōmunicate in his proper parishe) there is no Congregation; Neither in the twoe other feastes which ymediatly followe, to the ende they may attende to their other deuotiōs; And for the same
reason there is wonte to be no Congregation on Christmas day.

It is likewise omitted whē for any publique solemnitie, all, or the greater parte of the Sodalitie are likely to be hindered, or for other reasonable causes as the Father and Prefect shall iudge, geuing warning thereof, that all may knowe it.

div.head: About the Particular Congregations.
CHAPTER 4.
div.p: ON the first Saterday of euery moneth, & euery other time that there occurreth any vrgent necessitie, there is a Particuler Congregation imediatly helde after the General & the Father, or Prefect vse to geue notice thereof.

At this Particular Congregation there vseth ordinarily to be presēt the Father, the Prefect, the 2. Assistāes,
the Secretary & the Consultours only, Neuertheles sometimes also other officers, & others (not officers) are wont to be called, according to the matters which are to bee treated, as the Father or Prefect shall thincke good,

The order that is to be obserued is that which followeth first, are said a Patur noster, & Aue Maria, with the prayer Actiones nostras: Secondly, the thinges to be treated of, are proposed, & euery one to propose that which to him occurreth, for the seruice, and good of the Congregation, lastly the Congregation ended with an Aue Maries stella & the prayer Defende quaesumus Domine.

The first that speaketh his opinion about that which is proposed, is the Prefect, After whome followe the first & secōd Assistants, the Secretarie, and so the rest one after another, and all are to be secret.

Of the thinges that are determined in the particuler Congregation apperteyninge vnto all; Relation is to be geuē to the rest in the next Generall Congregation, to the end those thinges may be accordingely performed: And the Secretary as he hath care to set downe all in the booke of Actes, of the Congregation, so is it his care also to remember the Father & Prefect to doe the foresaid office in the generall Congregation.

div.head: About the ordinary Exercises of the Congregation.
CHAPTER 5.
div.p: THe ordinary exercises of the Congregation are these followinge.
First, some spiritual booke is read for a quarter of an hower while they come together.
Secondly, Masse is said.

Thirdly, if it be not necessary to resume the spirituall readinge for some occurrence, the Father, or some other Priest say the prayers before the Congregation, with the Letanies of our B. Lady, all answeringe thereunto.
Fowerthly, some pointes of meditation are briefly proposed by the Father, whereupon all doe afterwards meditate for one quarter of an hower in silence.
Fiftly, At the end of meditation, the Father is wonte to recommende to theire prayers, some particuler occurrence, or necessitie.
Sextly, The rest of the time is spent in some spirituall exercise, which accordinge to the dayes is chaunged.
Seauently, The exercise to be done in the next Congregation, and other such like thinges are notified.
Eghtly, The letters directed to the Congregation (when any come) are read.
Nintly, If any be to enter, they are then admitted.

Tently, The Secretarie readeth, or causeth to be read the Indulgēce of Rome, which they may gaine for that weeke, by sayinge seauen times the Paternosters, & Aue Maria, in some Churche of those of the Societie of Iesus, or in others (when in the place where they are, there be no Churches of the said Societie.)
Eleuently, The prayers of the Congregation, are said by the Father, or some other Prieste.
Twelftly, One other Masse is said for those who were not present at the first.
On euery Sunday, & certeine other feastes also, a conference is wonte to be made of some moral pointes, after the manner which more fully is afterwards said in the particuler Chapter thereof.

On the Saterday before the first Sunday of the moneth followinge when it may be, & that there is time, the Father is wont to geue some notice vnto all of the generall Communion, which is to be made on the said first Sunday.

Euery moneth a Masse is to be said by some Priest of the Sodalitie, appointed by the Prefecte: And the first Saterday of the moneth euery one is to heare a Masse, and one Nocturne, & three lessons of the office of the dead is to be said for the soules departed of the Congregation in generall, in the Oratory; And before it beginneth, the Secretary readeth, or causeth to be read the names of those of the Sodalitie deceased.

On the 2. Saterday of the moneth 3. appointed and warned by the Father, are to discourse vpon the Saincte, sentence, and vertue, which befalleth the Congregation, in common, when the distribution
of Sainctes is made: The first speaketh of the Saincte; the second of the vertue; the third of the sentence.
On the 3. Saterday there is no determinate exercise besides the foresaid, nor on the fouerth when the moneth chaunceth to haue fiue.
On the last Saterday is wont to be made the distributiō of Sainctes, with the other thinges which that action requireth, as is more fully said in his particuler chapter.

On the feastes of our Sauiour, of our B. Lady, of all Sainctes, & of the Apostles, there is no determinate exercise, neither of discourse, nor conferēce: But the Father is wont to see, & deliberate what maketh most to the purpose.
When the B. Sacrament is exposed, an exhortation is made after Masse.

On the day of the Immaculate Conception in the morninge, Masse
is said by the Father, or some other Priest; There is a generall Communiō to the which all men may be admitted; Afterwards are said the wonted prayers, with the Letanies of our B. Lady, & imediatly followeth a Sermon, and when there remayneth time there are said other Masses.

On the Saterday with in the Octaue of the commemoration of the Dead, a Masse of Requiem is said, and afterwards, the whole office of the dead, for them of the Congregation deceased; And the prayers wonte to be said before, & after the Congregation, the Letanies and the meditation are omitted, which likewise is to be obserued, when the whole office of the dead is said for any one of the Sodalitie departed.

On the dayes that the Election of officers is made, there is no meditation, nor other exercise, but that is obserued which is
afore said in his particuler Chapt.

On the day that the newe Prefect taketh possession, or on some other that the Father thincketh good, in place of the forenamed spirituall exercise after the Meditation, are wonte to be read the common Rules of the Congregation.

div.head: Of Masses.
CHAPTER 6.
div.p: THe Masse is wont to be said at the beginninge of the Congregation, & it beginneth alwaies at the hower which from time to time the Father doth appointe, without missinge any whit, that so the other exercises may haue their due time.
Another Masse also is to be said after the Congregation for those which haue denotion to heare it.

Al are wonte to be admonished precisely of the hower of Masse (as well in winter as in somer)
to the end that knowinge it, they may distribute pūctually the time for other thinges.
Vpon holy thursday Masse is said in the Oratorie, where there is a generall Communion, with a conference of the B Sacrament.
Vpon Easter eue Masse is said with the Prophecies, & Letanies.

When any of the Congregation should happen to be made Priest, it must be signified vnto the Father that he may inuite the rest to heare his first Masse, and to communicate (if they will) thereat; And at the end they kisse (for reuerence sake) his hand, And if time permit, they are wonte to make a conference of the excellencie & dignitie of Priest hoode; of the reuerenee which is due vnto Priestes, and of the vertues which they ought to haue.

div.head: Of the holy Communion
CHAPTER 7.
div.p: WHen any (for some necessary impediment) cometh not in time for to communicate with the rest at the first Masse, let him deferre it vntill the last, not to trouble the exercises of the Congregation.
In the Oratorie there is wont ordinarily to be a Father (vntill the time of the communion) for the commoditie of those which haue neede to confesse.
The time of cōmunion is after the Priest hath cōmunicated himselfe, before he taketh ablution.

div.head: Of Praier & Meditation.
CHAPTER 8.
div.p:
THe Meditation ordinarily is not to be omitted whā there is a Congregation, except on those
dayes in the which the election of officers is made; the office of the dead is said with three Nocturnes and when the B. Sacrament is exposed.
For the Meditation, the Father is briefly to propose the matter, & those pointes which he shall iudge to be most to the purpose; which sometimes he causeth to be read out of soome booke.

The Meditation doth not last aboue a quarter of an hower, and it is to be made after the letanies of our B. Lady, before all other spirituall exercises: And before they beginne, the Father, (after the pointes be geuen) or some other Priest, is wont to say the prayer Actiones nostras &c. & in the ende to beginne the Magnificat, standinge & the rest say forwards by turnes, some on the one side, & some on the other, & after all, he sayeth the prayer Famulis tuis quaesumus Domine.

div.head: Of the Conferences.
CHAPTER 9.
div.p: THe Conferences are to be made ordinarily vpon all the Sundayes in the yeare, vpon the Gospells which occurre, and at any other time when the Father shall thinke good vpon the same matters of the Gospells occurring, or others,
It belongeth to the Father to aske them indifferētly as he thinkes good, but he taketh heede not to aske but such as will take it in good parte.

If vnto those which the Father doth aske, nothinge doe occurre, It is sufficient, that puttinge of their hats they answere modestly that nothinge doth occurre vnto them; but when they would say any thinge, puttinge on their hatts lett them doe it aloude that they may be vnderstood by all, & the Father may now & then briefly
enterlace some thinge betwene euery ones discourse.

In this exercise of the Conferences, ostentation is to be shunned, & prolixitie, that others may haue time to speake, & they must auoyde speculatiue discourse, & with breuitye, and simplicitie attend vnto morall, & practicall considerations, by the which they may receaue profite, which in all is the ende of the Congregation, but particulerly in this conference.

div.head: Of the Praier of quarant-hower.
CHAPTER 10.
div.p:
WHen the B. Sacrament is to be exposed in the Oratory vpō the day appointed, the Altar and the Oratory, is decently to be adorned, but in such māner, that ostētation, & superfluitie be shūned,
& yet that nothinge be wantinge vnto the conuenient adorning of the same: And for this cause in particuler there must not be more then 24. lightes of white waxe placed with proportion.

That morninge Masse is to be said, & a generall communion is made thereat: And when there is commoditie for musick, some mottet may be sunge at the offertory at the eleuation, & in time of the generall Communion.

Masse beinge done, ymediatly (without loosinge of time) the letanies of our B. Lady are read by him that hath said the Masse, kneelinge before the Altar, & all answere deuoutly, & after hauing incensed the B. Sacrament, he setteth it in the place prepared.

After which there is a Sermon of half an hower, which ended, accordinge to the bill which is set vp neere vnto the doore of the Oratory, one after another all that
day they make their determinate howers of prayer, and sometime after dinner, the Father, or some body else maketh another Sermō
Moreouer when they haue cōmoditye, nowe & then some mottet, psalme, or other spirituall thinge may be sunge with a fewe, good and sweete voyces, which may helpe deuotion.
The same eueninge without other ceremonie, or solemnitie the B. Sacrament is couered vpon the Altar of the Oratory, the which afterwards is carried back into the Churche by the Fathers.

div.head: Of the Distribution of the Sainctes of euery moneth.
CHAPTER 11.
div.p:
VPon the last Saterday of euery moneth Sainctes are distributed for the moneth followinge;
The which is done with certeine litle papers prepared by the Sacristans against that day in sufficient nomber: Euery one of which papers is to haue the name of the Saincte, and the day of the Feast; a spirituall sentence, with a vertue vnto which they are especially, to attende; a particuler intention and the name of one of the Sodalitie to pray for: The manner to be obserued in the distributing of these Sainctes, is as followeth.

At the time appointed Vent Creator spititus being said with the prayer Deus qui corda Fidelium, All remayninge vppon their knees, the Father at the Altar draweth a paper, and the Saincte therein contained, is to be the next moneth followinge protectour of the whole Congregation, he readeth it publiquely, and all make a litle short prayer geuinge thanckes vnto the Saincte of the
moneth past for, the protection which he hath had of the Sodalitie, & intreating the newe one to take the protection of it in place of the other; Then risinge vp, they sit downe; The Father taketh a Saincte for himself, & readeth the paper after the same manner; Then followeth the Prefect, the first, and second Assistants, the Secretarie, and after, all the rest accordinge as they are called by the Secretarie, & euery one whilest the Father doth reade his Saincte, kneeles on the ground bare headed before the Altar, and hauing receaued the Saincte at the hand of the Father, he maketh a short prayer applyinge vnto his owne Saincte, and vnto himself in particuler that which is said before of the whole Sodalitie.

The distribution being ended, the letanies of the Sainctes are said, puttinge the name of the Saincte which hath hapned vnto the
whole Sodalitie in his proper place therein, and repeatinge it twice: And after the letanies, the prayer Concede quaesumus omnipotens Deus vt intercessio &c. is said.

The paper of the Saincte which hath hapned to the whole Sodalitie, is by the Secretarie placed where all may whensoeuer they will see it, & reade it: And on the same day those three are admonished, who the time appointed are to make some discourse vpon the Saincte, the sentence & the vertue.
Vnto those which were not present at the distribution, (that they be not depriued of so great a good,) the papers of the Sainctes are geuen after, without any other ceremonie.
Whilest the distribution of the Sainctes is made, all must attende with diligence vnto the spirituall sentences which are read procuringe to receaue profite thereby.

div.head: Of the visitinge of Hospitalls.
CHAPTER 12.
div.p:
ORdinarily vppon all the Fridayes of the yeare when they are not hindered by some other exercise in the Congregation, or by some other more vrgent occasiō, they are wont to goe in the morninge in competent numbers, & the Father with thē, to visite some Hospitall & to serue the sick in time of dinner, taking also occasion to geue them some spirituall repaste of good counsaile, that so charitie be exercised not only with their bodies, but also with their soules, in that half hower, or litle more, which is bestowed therein. They goe thither (of themselues) without obligation of meetinge in any other place (except in the said hospitall) And, (besides, some which are accustomed to goe ordinarily of their owne accord) It is the vse that
others be particulerly in the publique Congregatiō inuited vnto that exercise the sunday before, for the Friday followinge, who (hearinge themselues named) vncouer their heads, in token that they doe accepte the inuitation.

div.head: Of the spirituall Offeringes.
CHAPTER 13.
div.p: THey are wont to make some spirituall offeringes vnto God vnto our B. Lady, & vnto the Sainctes; The which do consiste in fastinges, disciplininges, and communions, visitinge of Hospitalls, of the prisoners, hearinge Masse, in almes, visitinge Holy places, the Rosarie, the beades, sayinge some office, vocall and mentall prayer, actes of vertue, & other workes of pietie, either for the whole moneth, weeke, or one day only, as euery one shall thinke best.

These offerings are wonte to be made vppon the dayes which the Father doth assigne, and vppon occasion, of some feast followinge; as of the Conception of the most B. Virgin, of all Sainctes, of Aduent, of the Epiphanie, & the Anuntiation, on which (being the day our Congregation beganne) an annuall memory is made) with thanckesgeuing, vnto God, & vnto his most holy Mother; & in acknowledgement of so greeat a fauour, somewhat is offered vnto them, of our pouerty, chiefly on that day, when the Sonne of God became man for our sake; And they must pray for the happie progresse, & spirituall aduauncement of the Congregation.

And alwaies when they vnderstand of any trouble, or vrgēt necessitie of the Christian common wealthe, (especially of our Countrey) like offeringes are made vnto our Sauiour, to his most
Holy Mother, & vnto the Sainctes, that they would mitigate the wrath of Almightie God and be our Patrons, and Intercessours in those necessities.

The foresaid offeringes are made in writtinge, & the wordes, & intention is such, that they are not helde for vowes, but only for deuoute purposes, by the neglectinge whereof they commit no sinne, but only the merite is lost which was to be had for that good worke: And in the bill is written the name and surname of him which offers it, the which bill they bringe from home readie made, or else they write it in the Oratorie it self in papers, which for that purpose are prepared, reteyninge with them a copie for their memorie; Afterwards euery one (as he sits in the Oratory) goeth to carrie his bil to the boxe, for this purpose placed at the foote of the Crucifixe before the Altar
kissinge first the foote of the Crucifixe: And these billes come not to the hands of others, but of the Father only, who burneth them; And the memory of that which is conteyned in them serueth only for the spirituall good of the offerour.

div.head: Of Candelmasse & Palme Sunday.
CHAPTER 14.
div.p: VPon Candelmas day & Palme Sunday, the Father, or some other Prieste, blesseth the cādles, & Palmes, which are prouided, of the same fashion, & bignes for all.

The distribution of the same is made afterwards amongst all the Congregation which are present in the Oratory; first vnto the Father, then vnto the Prefect, & the rest of the Officers which sit vpō
the Benche and afterwards vnto the others, beginninge in order from the top of the benche.
The Sacristans haue care to prouide candels for that day & bowes of oliues with litle crosses of palmes.

div.head: Of the accusinge themselues of their owne faults.
CHAPTER 15.
div.p:
IT is the custome nowe & then of some more feruēte to accuse themselues publiquely of their faultes and defectes committed in the obseruinge of the Rules & the like, & kneelinge downe before the Father, and the Prefect, they humbly aske penaunce in publique, which the Father geueth thē. In these actions, (besides that they geue edification vnto others, and become more exact obseruers of
the Rules) they merite very much before Almighty God; The fittest time for their accusation, is after the meditation, and before the Conference beginne.

div.head: The manner of cominge in, & goinge out of the Oratorie.
CHAPTER 16.
div.p:
ALl at their entringe in to the Oratory, first take holy water, & then signe their names in the Table of those that frequent: And those that will communicate doe signe their names in the Table of communicantes, to the ende that the Sacristans may knowe the nōber of those which are to cōmunicate, & may prouide sufficient hostes. This beinge done, kneelinge on both knees, they make a litle prayer as long as they thincke good, soo that the exercise be not
begunne. But cominge in time of meditation, they meditate together with the rest; And if they come whilest the pointes of meditation are geuinge, or in time of conference, of sermon, or exhortation, It is sufficient they kneele downe, & make a short prayer, & after reuerēce made to the Altar, they turne themselues likewise to those that sit vpon the benches, & it is sufficient that the Father, or Prefect vncouer vnto thē, to auoyde disturbance, Then they sit downe in a place, in which they may beseene comodiously procuringe to sit close (as much as they can) to leaue place for others.
In sittinge, the 26. common Rule is exactly obserued, proceedinge without ceremonie, or precedence: Chayers are only geuen to the Father & Magistrates.

In goinge forth, they obserue the same, without hauing any rerespect of Precidēcie, the which is
alwaies cause of disunion, and disagreeinge of opinion.

div.head: Of the manner of admittinge into the Sodality.
CHAPTER 17.
div.p: IN the memorialls which they do giue vp that desire to be receaued, they are to write their names, surnames, countrey, profession, and dwellinge place, and whē the persons are not knowne the diligēce is obserued, which is set downe in the cōmon Rule 31.

After they are receaued to the Probation, they vse in the 3. monethes of it, to be present at all the spirituall exercises which ordinarily are performed, to the end, that by their proceedinge they may be knowne, & a iudgement made of them; and on the other side, they seeinge that
which others doe, learne the obseruance of the Rules, but they are not permitted to haue suffrage in the election, or admission, or any other busenes which is treated of in the Congregation.

The time of their Probation being expired, their Instructours doe propounde to the whole Congregation their admission (but yet in the absence of those which are to be admitted) & their Instructours make the relatiō according to the contētes in their particuler Rules: After the wonted prayers are said (that is Veni Creator spiritus, and the prayer of the holy Ghoste) they goe about the choyce, & the greater parte of the suffrages preuayleth, & if they receaue him, they aduise him by his Instructours of his receauinge, & in the nex Congregation they cause him to be brought in by the same Instructours & they receaue him with the accustomed prayers, & ceremonies,
being met in the entrance by 2. Sacristans, and brought betwene thē to kneele downe hard by the Altar, where they make a litle prayer, which being done, the Sacristans carry them to the benche, where they are embraced in name of all the Congregation, first of the Father, then of the Magistates, & they put them in minde of the plenary Indulgence which they obteyne: And lastly they say Te Deum Laudamus, with the prayer Da nobis quaesumus Domine perseuerantem &c.

It is not the custome to admittany of another Congregatiō to ours, whose patentes be not very well examined, or at least the person himself, and certeine notice is to be procured whether he haue the qualities required in one of our Congregation.

But Prelates are so priuiledged that without any probation, or further triall, it sufficeth they signifie to the Father or Prefect their
desire to enter into the Congregatiō, & so to be admitted.

div.head: The manner of recommendinge himself to God in the Morninge.
div.p: TO geue thanckes to Almigtie God for the benefites receaued in generall, & in particuler for hauing passed well that night. 2. To offer himself wholy in the hands of Almighty God, and pray that he keepe him, and geue him grace to doe that day al thinges accordinge to his will.
3. To consider those thinges, which doe most draw him to sinne, resoluinge to absteine from them & withall renewinge his good purpose of spirituall life.

4. To aske helpe to that end of our B. Lady, and to recommend
himself to all the companie of the blessed of heauen, and in Particuler to his Saincte protectour for that moneth.
5. Lastly to say thrice Pater noster & thrice Aue Maria for all the faithfull aliue & dead, & to goe deuoutly to Masse offeringe that sacrifice for his sinnes & the necessities of the Holy Churche.

div.head: A manner of examininge our Concience at night
div.p: TO giue thanckes to Almightie God for the benefites receaued generally, & in particuler for those receaued that day.
To aske grace of our Sauiour, & true light to knowe, & hate sinne & in particuler the errours comitted that day.

To aske accounte of his conscience of all that wherein he shall haue offended Almightie God
that day in thought, word, deede and omission, attending to those defects to which he is most inclined.
To aske of almighty God humbly pardon of whatsoeuer fault or sinne which he shall finde
To haue a firme purpose to preserue himself by the helpe of almighty God from sinne hereafter, with purpose to confesse himself endinge with Pater noster, Aue Maria & the Creede.

SOme fewe Chapters of the Roman Copie concerning certaine particular officers, & some kinde of penaunces, & expences, (not makinge for our present purpose) are in this edition omitted, kept notwithstandinge by the Secretarie to be printed, & practised when it shalbe iudged conuenient.
